intro: Quercus rubra var. subserrata, commonly known as the scarlet oak, is a deciduous tree native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its distinctive, sharply toothed leaves that turn vibrant red in the fall. The tree produces small, spiny acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It typically grows to a height of 20–40 feet and has a broad, spreading crown. Botanically, it belongs to the Fagaceae family and is closely related to other oak species within the genus Quercus.
